qas.question: On what date did the companies that became the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company get consolidated?
Name the individual that consolidated the companies that were to become the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company.
In what year did the companies owned by Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company finally integrate?
Where was the CTR Business office?
In 1933 the four companies owned by CTR had how many employees?
Where was Charles Ranlett Flint originally from?
In what year was Endicott created by Charles Ranlett Flint?
In what state was Endicott consolidated into one company?
How many employees worked at the holding company in 1911?
What was the original name of the Endicott company?

context: On <a0_0><b6_0>June 16, 1911<b6_0/><a0_0/>, their four companies were consolidated in <b7_0>New York<b7_0/> State by <a1_0>Charles Ranlett Flint<a1_0/> to form the <b9_0>Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company<b9_0/> (CTR). CTR's business office was in <a3_0><b5_0>Endicott<b5_0/><a3_0/>. The individual companies owned by CTR continued to operate using their established names until the businesses were integrated in <a2_0>1933<a2_0/> and the holding company eliminated. The four companies had <a4_0><b8_0>1,300<b8_0/> employees<a4_0/> and offices and plants in Endicott and Binghamton, New York; Dayton, Ohio; Detroit, Michigan; Washington, D.C.; and Toronto. They manufactured machinery for sale and lease, ranging from commercial scales and industrial time recorders, meat and cheese slicers, to tabulators and punched cards.
